snippet.textDisplay:
Ah... I love this music.
This is the part of the game that I noticed that my favorite character was Midna. I had never worried so much about a character before. It was raining and, although we didn't had a timer, I was desperate to save her. It's pretty obvious that she can't die in this part, but I appreciate the fact that they didn't include a timer, because of the uncertainty, I didn't know if I had a time limit or not, so I just dashed through this part as fast as I could so that she wouldn't die.
I hate the fact that this music is interrupted by the battle music though, even on the HD Remake, it breaks the feeling completely, but this is still one of my favorite moments from all the games that I played.
Another thing thought, Midna's Desperation Hour (Midna's Lament) from Super Smash Bros. is a clearer version, it's, sadly, better than the game's version, you can notice how the melody from the piano is a bit muffed in this version.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ah... I love this music.
This is the part of the game that I noticed that my favorite character was Midna. I had never worried so much about a character before. It was raining and, although we didn't had a timer, I was desperate to save her. It's pretty obvious that she can't die in this part, but I appreciate the fact that they didn't include a timer, because of the uncertainty, I didn't know if I had a time limit or not, so I just dashed through this part as fast as I could so that she wouldn't die.
I hate the fact that this music is interrupted by the battle music though, even on the HD Remake, it breaks the feeling completely, but this is still one of my favorite moments from all the games that I played.
Another thing thought, Midna's Desperation Hour (Midna's Lament) from Super Smash Bros. is a clearer version, it's, sadly, better than the game's version, you can notice how the melody from the piano is a bit muffed in this version.

snippet.textDisplay: Despite this being one of my least favorite Zelda titles, this song still strikes a powerful chord. I wasn't fond of Midna's sudden change of heart, but that still doesn't mean that I never showed worry towards her during this sequence. I think that this moment of the game was the one part that still aged well enough in my eyes. Lovely song, one of my favorites.

snippet.textDisplay: @TheCuster58 You're right, the Ice arrow is a "cool" example. The developers make sure it works decently, prolly in a menial way by shooting Ice arrows at any would-be targets in the entire game,. But the bow-arrow fundamental code and testing is already accounted for. All they need are a few extra graphical effects and a "stopper" for the moving enemy. Inserting "new" items by modifying old items, is not hard. Red bombs, anyone? Upgradable boomerang? If you have a gamemechanic, make use of it!
snippet.textOriginal: @TheCuster58 You're right, the Ice arrow is a "cool" example. The developers make sure it works decently, prolly in a menial way by shooting Ice arrows at any would-be targets in the entire game,. But the bow-arrow fundamental code and testing is already accounted for. All they need are a few extra graphical effects and a "stopper" for the moving enemy. Inserting "new" items by modifying old items, is not hard. Red bombs, anyone? Upgradable boomerang? If you have a gamemechanic, make use of it!

snippet.textDisplay: @SupraDarky It's a conundrum. If they have cool gear and items (Bomerang, bombs, hookshot) they want to make them useful in the game (stunnable enemies, breakable walls, attachable spots). But implementing items requires RL dev resources. Items in hidden caves are items the playersbase can miss and not experience. By putting nice items in mandatory temples they ensure that all players will enjoy them and other resources are used to improve the rest of the game. The music for example =)
snippet.textOriginal: @SupraDarky It's a conundrum. If they have cool gear and items (Bomerang, bombs, hookshot) they want to make them useful in the game (stunnable enemies, breakable walls, attachable spots). But implementing items requires RL dev resources. Items in hidden caves are items the playersbase can miss and not experience. By putting nice items in mandatory temples they ensure that all players will enjoy them and other resources are used to improve the rest of the game. The music for example =)

snippet.textDisplay: @chcoman123 Like I said, they are BOTH correct. Midna's Lament and Midna's Desperate Hour are names for the same song. Not just one. Just because in America we call it, Midna's Lament doesn't mean that's the only name and real name. This happens a lot with other games when translating from Japanese to English. I've seen it countless times.
snippet.textOriginal: @chcoman123 Like I said, they are BOTH correct. Midna's Lament and Midna's Desperate Hour are names for the same song. Not just one. Just because in America we call it, Midna's Lament doesn't mean that's the only name and real name. This happens a lot with other games when translating from Japanese to English. I've seen it countless times.

snippet.textDisplay: This music makes me think of walking down a road in the fall... with a lot of leaves falling down around me. By myself... a few kids playing games outside. I continue walking, emotionless, as if ignoring the children's joy, but I am not sad. The kids stop playing for a moment, and watch me walk by. I am empty.
snippet.textOriginal: This music makes me think of walking down a road in the fall... with a lot of leaves falling down around me. By myself... a few kids playing games outside. I continue walking, emotionless, as if ignoring the children's joy, but I am not sad. The kids stop playing for a moment, and watch me walk by. I am empty.

snippet.textDisplay:
Best song in the game. 

Twilight Princess was okay, though I'd still rank it lower than MM and maybe even WW. I disliked how the special item you got in each dungeon seemingly became useless beyond the dungeon you got it in and getting a Heart Piece or two. What I liked about MM was the crazy amount of sidequests, along with the lore.
snippet.textOriginal:

I disliked how the special item you got in each dungeon seemingly became useless beyond the dungeon you got it in and getting a Heart Piece or two. What I liked about MM was the crazy amount of sidequests, along with the lore.

snippet.textDisplay: As an aside, one thing I hope they fix in the next Zelda are the rewards you get outside the dungeons. It's a problem that's been present throughout most of the series, where I'll find a cool hidden cave or something. I go inside, there's a fun mini-labyrinth, and in the end all I get is either 100 Rupees (when I already have 999 so the chest stays closed) or a piece of heart. It's rarely a surprising reward.
snippet.textOriginal: As an aside, one thing I hope they fix in the next Zelda are the rewards you get outside the dungeons. It's a problem that's been present throughout most of the series, where I'll find a cool hidden cave or something. I go inside, there's a fun mini-labyrinth, and in the end all I get is either 100 Rupees (when I already have 999 so the chest stays closed) or a piece of heart. It's rarely a surprising reward.

snippet.textDisplay: @Masz52 That's the thing though, for me Zelda is all about dungeons. It's the number one reason I love this series so much. Even then, while MM definitely had the upper hand in terms of things to do outside the dungeons, I spent a lot of fun time outside of them as well in TP. It had a lot of mini-games and hidden caves or spots you could go back to with your new dungeon treasures.
snippet.textOriginal: @Masz52 That's the thing though, for me Zelda is all about dungeons. It's the number one reason I love this series so much. Even then, while MM definitely had the upper hand in terms of things to do outside the dungeons, I spent a lot of fun time outside of them as well in TP. It had a lot of mini-games and hidden caves or spots you could go back to with your new dungeon treasures.

snippet.textDisplay: TP is my least favorite 3D Zelda. Relatively weak soundtrack, uninteresting locales, static towns, pointless quests, boring characters. It's just not cohesively designed.

snippet.textDisplay: Majora's Mask my fav namely because the town was the first time it actually felt like a real town, like the people were real and to this day one of the only games to still do just that. Breath life into everything. Kinda ironic since it's the Zelda where the psychopath of a villain is actually killing everything.Probably Nintendo's way of getting everyone to care for the people a little more.They did it here in TP with Midna and look at all of these people caring!(my comments relate to the vid)

snippet.textDisplay: Wind Waker would arguably be my favorite actually, but I cannot stand the Triforce section of it, I really can't. It's even left many of my friends to denounce the game's existance in fact and mark it as the worst. I feel that's a bit much but that part of the game I could do without.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sad, and I can say this at the same time very dramatic, racing to save a life.
And since we bring it up, MM my favorite Zelda, then OoT, WW, LttP, TP takes 5th. This order partially due to the soundtracks, partially with their styles and it also has something to do with the overrall feel and pacing of the games.

snippet.textDisplay:
MM is probably my second or most favorite Zelda game. Of course I hated the time limit when I was younger, but I don't mind it these days.

I recently read something that did a very good job stating why MM is awesome but it's too big to post here.

As for TP, it's like a better version of OoT to me.

MM is probably my second or most favorite Zelda game. Of course I hated the time limit when I was younger, but I don't mind it these days.

As for TP, it's like a better version of OoT to me.

snippet.textDisplay: @SupraDarky The lack of dungeons didn't bother me because there was a ton of stuff to do outside of that. That's something I didn't like about TP. It  felt like you were just going from dungeon to dungeon, while MM you had like a shit ton of side quests you could do in between.
snippet.textOriginal: @SupraDarky The lack of dungeons didn't bother me because there was a ton of stuff to do outside of that. That's something I didn't like about TP. snippet.textDisplay: @XxDJXepherxX Definately give it another shot. So much of that game can't be appreciated when we're young, out mostly for the gameplay. It's the atmosphere that really sells that game. You thought this part of the game was heavy? Try not feeling something when Anju sits in the inn as the moon is falling, saying she will wait, all to one of the most... final pieces of music ever.

snippet.textDisplay: @SupraDarky Woah, it's my favorite Zelda game, even my favorite video game in general. It's really good, give it another chance. The atmosphere and music is great, and the whole mask thing is frikkin awesome, with the 3 forms of link. And the NPC interaction is great, you really feel for these people as they struggle to get somewhere in the last days of their lives, over and over again.
snippet.textOriginal: @SupraDarky Woah, it's my favorite Zelda game, even my favorite video game in general. It's really good, give it another chance. And the NPC interaction is great, you really feel for these people as they struggle to get somewhere in the last days of their lives, over and over again.

snippet.textDisplay: While OoT definitely had the bigger impact on me at the time, Twilight Princess is actually my favorite 3D Zelda (Link's Awakening being my favorite 2D Zelda). Few people usually agree with me. When it comes to the dungeons, I really find it unmatched. Plus I actually really like the Shadow world with its unique and dark atmosphere (and impressive graphics).
snippet.textOriginal: While OoT definitely had the bigger impact on me at the time, Twilight Princess is actually my favorite 3D Zelda (Link's Awakening being my favorite 2D Zelda). Few people usually agree with me. When it comes to the dungeons, I really find it unmatched. Plus I actually really like the Shadow world with its unique and dark atmosphere (and impressive graphics).
